description.narrative:
The potential development impact of the Project is composed of the following: (i) increased access to finance for VSEs (including women owned VSEs) and VSEs owned by refugees that are unserved by banking services, where MSMEs financing gap stands at US$6.5 billion or 18% of GDP; (ii) improved borrowing terms of VSEs and host/refugee communities finance by introducing long-tenor loans; & (iii) through the AS work, IFC will address MfW's internal capabilities in product offering by providing new VSEs products, which is key to MfW's borrowers.
Moreover, IFC anticipates that the Project would impact the microfinance market by a wider offering of longer-term loans by MFIs. IFC will support the increase of financial inclusion for VSEs as well as refugees; both are under served segments. It will also act as a demonstration effect for other investors to support access to finance for MFIs and support efforts for financial inclusion of host/refugee communities.

The proposed project entails a local currency loan equivalent to US$10 million with a 5-year tenor to Micro Fund for Women (MfW or the Company), the largest and leading microfinance institution (MFI) in Jordan. The proceeds of the IFC loan would be utilized by MfW to support its lending program to very small enterprises (VSEs), with a focus on VSEs owned or led by women. Moreover, part of the lending will be earmarked for on-lending to refugees and their host communities.

name.narrative: MfW is headquartered in Amman, Jordan, with a network of 61 branches covering most of Jordan cities. Investments can be made throughout the Country.
